div.p: Because of something which was previously said one can ask: Is the cogitative soul able to cognize material substances?

1st arg. First, one can argue for the affirmative answer on account of what Averroes sais in book II of his De anima: When a sense apprehends its proper objects, along with them it also apprehends individual intentions of different kinds according to genera and species; i.e., it apprehends the intention of this individual human being and the intention of this individual horse. But it is well known that this individual human being is a substance, and this individual horse is a substance; and likewise about other individual things. Under “sense”, Averroes in his sentence understands either a particular sense like sight, hearing etc. or the cogitative power, which is a power of the sensitive soul. If he understands a particular sense, then we have to assume that the cogitative soul, which is a more noble and more perfect power than any particular sense, will even stronger cognize objects of this kind = individual material substances. If he under “sense” understands the cogitative soul, then we have immediately got the point. Therefore etc.

And in the following comment Averroes says that it belongs accidentally to the senses to apprehend differences – in particular substantial differences – among individuals, insofar as they are individuals; this belongs to the senses not insofar as they are just senses, but insofar as they are human senses. For it manifestly belongs to human senses to apprehend individual intentions of substances that are considered by the intellect. Therefore etc.

2nd arg. Moreover, if the cogitative power did not cognize a material substance, then the intellect could not cognize it either, which is nonsense because the intellect’s proper function is to cognize any material substance. The inference can be proved as follows: an act of the cogitative power is necessary in order to have an act of intellection, in particular when the objects of acts of intellection are material things; this is evident from what is said by Aristotle in De anima III: for whoever is understanding, it is necessary to consider some phantasm. Therefore etc.

To the opposite One can argue for the opposite view: if the cogitative soul cognized material forms, then for the same reason the cogitative soul would cognize itself, since the cogitative soul is a material substance or form, as it is manifest from what was said previously. This, however, appears to be impossible, for a material and corporeal form can never reflect about itself, as it is commonly assumed by reference to the Liber de causis. For this reason etc.

This reason is confirmed by the following argument: the cogitative soul is naturally apt to cognize actual beings only by means of their proper species. For there is no reason for which the cogitative soul should cognize one being by means of its proper species and another being without its proper species. But the cogitative soul cannot receive the proper species of itself, otherwise one and the same subject – i.e. the human body – would have the very same form both according to the form’s real being and according to the form’s spiritual being; but this is impossible. For this reason etc.

Response: On this topic there are two probable opinions. 1. The first opinion is that the human cogitative soul only cognizes material substances in themselves and formally, if it = the cogitative soul receives their proper species; for the cogitative soul can only cognize something properly and in itself and formally, if it = the cogitative soul receives the proper species of it. This assumption is supposed to be manifest. But the cogitative soul cannot receive the proper species of any material substance. For this species has to be a substance in a way, as it has been said previously, and the cogitative soul cannot receive in itself anything belonging to the genus of substance, since it = the cogitative soul is itself a substantial form and act. For this reason etc.

One could say, however, that the cogitative soul indeed cognizes individual properties that exist in a material substance and are not apprehended by any particular sense. These properties are called non-sensible intentions, and they are what Averroes calls intentions of individual substances: such as, for instance, this goodness, this malice, this fatherhood, this being-son/daughter, this action, this passion, and similar properties that belong to other categories and which are neither common nor proper sensible objects; these properties cannot be apprehended by particular senses. But the cogitative soul cognizes intentions of this kind, as all philosophers who have spoken about the difference between the powers of the human soul – in particular Averroes, Albert, Avicenna, Algazel – testify. And this can also be proved sufficiently by the following argument: since the cogitative power is as a cognitive power nobler and more excellent than any particular sense and the common sense, it =the cogitative power must cognize things that cannot be cognized by these latter powers, and such things can only be intentions of the kind I have mentioned. For this reason etc.

This view can be confirmed according to the intention of Aristotle and Averroes. For it is known that the human soul,
which inheres in the human body, is nobler than any other inherent = bodily soul und must have a power that is nobler than any powers of other animals. That power can only be the cogitative power, which reasons about particular things that have been apprehended. Therefore it is called a certain reason, according to what Averroes says in this third book of his De anima. For this reason etc.

2. The second opinion could be that the cogitative power cognizes material substances by means of their individual proper species, but only insofar as the species of this kind that are received in the cogitative soul do not belong to the category of substance, but to the category of accident, for instance to the category of quality; these species nonetheless represent material substances to the extent that they are proper effects of them. And it does not appear to be inconvenient that a material substance immediately produces some spiritual accident = quality in a subject that is naturally apt to receive it, when the proximate agent is together with the patient, as it is evident from Physics VII. But a material substance is not together with the human cogitative soul in the way a stone, a piece of wood and things of this kind are; for this reason we will have to admit that a material substance of this kind produces its species in the medium existing between the cogitative soul and the material substance, and through this medium it = the material substance produces its species in the organ of the senses and further on in the cogitative soul. But from this it does not follow that the particular senses cognize the material substance, for they are not appointed to cognize it by itself, nor do they receive the species of the substance according to spiritual being, as it is required for cognition. Oh might I know what is true in this question! If some new ideas appear to my mind, I will write them down at another place.

To the 1st argument: Both reasons and authorities in favor of both opinions can be avoided according to what we have just said. Thus, when Averroes says that the sense apprehends the individual intention of this human being and of this horse, we can reply that under “individual intention” he does not understands the very substantial form of the human being or of the horse, but some non-sensible property which belongs to such an individual, so that the sense = the cogitative power would cognize this paternity, this being-son/being-daughter, this capacity of laughing, this bodily strength, this aptitude to walk etc.

Likewise, when Averroes says that it belongs accidentally to the senses to apprehend the substantial differences of individuals, we can reply that under “substantial differences” he understands some non-sensible properties deriving from the substance of an individual; Averroes also calls them individual intentions of the substances considered by the intellect.

To the 2nd argument: To the second argument – which was a reason argument, not an authority argument – we can reply as follows: in order for the intellect to cognize material substances it suffices that the cogitative power cognizes them by their proper accidents, particularly by operations which belong to them = material substances as proper accidents per se. Likewise, in order for the intellect to understand immaterial substances it is not necessary that the cogitative power cognizes them – this is even impossible, since a material and organic power is absolutely not able to cognize any spiritual and incorporeal thing –, but it suffices that the cogitative power apprehends proper effects of them = immaterial substances, i.e. the perpetual and uniform motions of the stars, as it is evident from Physics VIII. For this reason, etc.

To the “to the opposite”: The argument “to the opposite” – namely that the cogitative soul, for the very same reason for which it would cognize material substances, should also cognize itself – is very complicate and not very fine. Nonetheless we may reply that the cogitative soul does not cognize itself by itself or through its proper species, whether this species is taken to belong to the category of substance or to a category of accidents. But if the cogitative soul cognizes itself at all, then this is so only by its operation, since the cogitative soul knows that it is cogitating, which is its proper and intrinsic activity. Thus, the cogitative soul perhaps does not cognize its own operation, for it is an organic and corporeal power; but it is the intellect that cognizes it = the operation of the cogitative power, and human beings in turn cognizes this operation by means of the intellect. If someone said that she is aware of her cogitating and she knows her cogitating, then we might reply to her that she is abusing her cogitating; in fact she should say that the intellect and not the cogitative power understands her cogitating.
I do not know anything more about this topic. Thus, try to think yourself, too. And so on.
